KeymapManager.name: KeymapManager

classMethods.name: buildKeydownEvent
classMethods.summary: Create a keydown DOM event for testing purposes.
classMethods.description: Create a keydown DOM event for testing purposes.

arguments.name: key
arguments.description: The key or keyIdentifier of the event. For example, `'a'`, `'1'`, `'escape'`, `'backspace'`, etc.

children.name: ctrl
children.description: A {Boolean} indicating the ctrl modifier key

children.name: alt
children.description: A {Boolean} indicating the alt modifier key

children.name: shift
children.description: A {Boolean} indicating the shift modifier key

children.name: cmd
children.description: A {Boolean} indicating the cmd modifier key

children.name: which
children.description: A {Number} indicating `which` value of the event. See the docs for KeyboardEvent for more information.

children.name: target
children.description: The target element of the event.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: An {Object} containing any of the following:

children.name: defaultTarget
children.description: This will be used as the target of events whose target is `document.body` to allow for a catch-all element when nothing is focused.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: An {Object} containing properties to assign to the keymap.  You can pass custom properties to be used by extension methods. The following properties are also supported:

instanceMethods.name: onDidMatchBinding
instanceMethods.summary:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes completely
match a key binding.
instanceMethods.description:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes completely
match a key binding.

children.name: keystrokes
children.description: {String} of keystrokes that matched the binding.

children.name: binding
children.description: {KeyBinding} that the keystrokes matched.

children.name: keyboardEventTarget
children.description: DOM element that was the target of the most  recent keyboard event.

children.name: event
children.description: {Object} with the following keys:

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: {Function} to be called when keystrokes match a binding.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable} on which `.dispose()` can be called to unsubscribe.

instanceMethods.name: onDidPartiallyMatchBindings
instanceMethods.summary:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes partially
match a binding.
instanceMethods.description:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes partially
match a binding.

children.name: keystrokes
children.description: {String} of keystrokes that matched the binding.

children.name: partiallyMatchedBindings
children.description: {KeyBinding}s that the keystrokes partially matched.

children.name: keyboardEventTarget
children.description: DOM element that was the target of the most recent keyboard event.

children.name: event
children.description: {Object} with the following keys:

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: {Function} to be called when keystrokes partially match a binding.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable} on which `.dispose()` can be called to unsubscribe.

instanceMethods.name: onDidFailToMatchBinding
instanceMethods.summary:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes fail to match
any bindings.
instanceMethods.description:
Invoke the given callback when one or more keystrokes fail to match
any bindings.

children.name: keystrokes
children.description: {String} of keystrokes that matched the binding.

children.name: keyboardEventTarget
children.description: DOM element that was the target of the most  recent keyboard event.

children.name: event
children.description: {Object} with the following keys:

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: {Function} to be called when keystrokes fail to match any bindings.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable} on which `.dispose()` can be called to unsubscribe.

instanceMethods.name: onDidFailToReadFile
instanceMethods.summary: Invoke the given callback when a keymap file not able to be loaded.
instanceMethods.description: Invoke the given callback when a keymap file not able to be loaded.

children.name: message
children.description: {String} the error message.

children.name: stack
children.description: {String} the error stack trace.

children.name: error
children.description: {Object} with the following keys:

arguments.name: callback
arguments.description: {Function} to be called when a keymap file is unloaded.

returnValues.description: Returns a {Disposable} on which `.dispose()` can be called to unsubscribe.

instanceMethods.name: add
instanceMethods.summary: Add sets of key bindings grouped by CSS selector.
instanceMethods.description: Add sets of key bindings grouped by CSS selector.

arguments.name: source
arguments.description: A {String} (usually a path) uniquely identifying the given bindings so they can be removed later.

arguments.name: bindings
arguments.description: An {Object} whose top-level keys point at sub-objects mapping keystroke patterns to commands.

instanceMethods.name: findKeyBindings
instanceMethods.summary: Get the key bindings for a given command and optional target.
instanceMethods.description: Get the key bindings for a given command and optional target.

children.name: keystrokes
children.description: A {String} representing one or more keystrokes, such as 'ctrl-x ctrl-s'

children.name: command
children.description: A {String} representing the name of a command, such as 'editor:backspace'

children.name: target
children.description: An optional DOM element constraining the search. If this parameter is supplied, the call will only return bindings that can be invoked by a KeyboardEvent originating from the target element.

arguments.name: params
arguments.description: An {Object} whose keys constrain the binding search:

instanceMethods.name: loadKeymap
instanceMethods.summary: Load the key bindings from the given path.
instanceMethods.description: Load the key bindings from the given path.

arguments.name: path
arguments.description: A {String} containing a path to a file or a directory. If the path is a directory, all files inside it will be loaded.

children.name: watch
children.description: If `true`, the keymap will also reload the file at the given path whenever it changes. This option cannot be used with directory paths.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: An {Object} containing the following optional keys:

instanceMethods.name: watchKeymap
instanceMethods.summary:
Cause the keymap to reload the key bindings file at the given path
whenever it changes.
instanceMethods.description:
Cause the keymap to reload the key bindings file at the given path
whenever it changes.

This method doesn't perform the initial load of the key bindings file. If
that's what you're looking for, call {::loadKeymap} with `watch: true`.

arguments.name: path
arguments.description: A {String} containing a path to a file or a directory. If the path is a directory, all files inside it will be loaded.

instanceMethods.name: handleKeyboardEvent
instanceMethods.summary:
Dispatch a custom event associated with the matching key binding for
the given `KeyboardEvent` if one can be found.
instanceMethods.description:
Dispatch a custom event associated with the matching key binding for
the given `KeyboardEvent` if one can be found.

If a matching binding is found on the event's target or one of its
ancestors, `.preventDefault()` is called on the keyboard event and the
binding's command is emitted as a custom event on the matching element.

If the matching binding's command is 'native!', the method will terminate
without calling `.preventDefault()` on the keyboard event, allowing the
browser to handle it as normal.

If the matching binding's command is 'unset!', the search will continue from
the current element's parent.

If the matching binding's command is 'abort!', the search will terminate
without dispatching a command event.

If the event's target is `document.body`, it will be treated as if its
target is `.defaultTarget` if that property is assigned on the keymap.

instanceMethods.name: keystrokeForKeyboardEvent
instanceMethods.summary: Translate a keydown event to a keystroke string.
instanceMethods.description: Translate a keydown event to a keystroke string.

instanceMethods.name: getPartialMatchTimeout
instanceMethods.summary:
Get the number of milliseconds allowed before pending states caused
by partial matches of multi-keystroke bindings are terminated.
instanceMethods.description:
Get the number of milliseconds allowed before pending states caused
by partial matches of multi-keystroke bindings are terminated.

KeymapManager.summary:
Allows commands to be associated with keystrokes in a
context-sensitive way. In Atom, you can access a global instance of this
object via `atom.keymap`.
KeymapManager.description:
Allows commands to be associated with keystrokes in a
context-sensitive way. In Atom, you can access a global instance of this
object via `atom.keymap`.

Key bindings are plain JavaScript objects containing **CSS selectors** as
their top level keys, then **keystroke patterns** mapped to commands.

```cson
'.workspace':
  'ctrl-l': 'package:do-something'
  'ctrl-z': 'package:do-something-else'
'.mini.editor':
  'enter': 'core:confirm'
```

When a keystroke sequence matches a binding in a given context, a custom DOM
event with a type based on the command is dispatched on the target of the
keyboard event.

To match a keystroke sequence, the keymap starts at the target element for the
keyboard event. It looks for key bindings associated with selectors that match
the target element. If multiple match, the most specific is selected. If there
is a tie in specificity, the most recently added binding wins. If no bindings
are found for the events target, the search is repeated again for the target's
parent node and so on recursively until a binding is found or we traverse off
the top of the document.

When a binding is found, its command event is always dispatched on the
original target of the keyboard event, even if the matching element is higher
up in the DOM. In addition, `.preventDefault()` is called on the keyboard
event to prevent the browser from taking action. `.preventDefault` is only
called if a matching binding is found.

Command event objects have a non-standard method called `.abortKeyBinding()`.
If your command handler is invoked but you programmatically determine that no
action can be taken and you want to allow other bindings to be matched, call
`.abortKeyBinding()` on the event object. An example of where this is useful
is binding snippet expansion to `tab`. If `snippets:expand` is invoked when
the cursor does not follow a valid snippet prefix, we abort the binding and
allow `tab` to be handled by the default handler, which inserts whitespace.

Multi-keystroke bindings are possible. If a sequence of one or more keystrokes
*partially* matches a multi-keystroke binding, the keymap enters a pending
state. The pending state is terminated on the next keystroke, or after
{::partialMatchTimeout} milliseconds has elapsed. When the pending state is
terminated via a timeout or a keystroke that leads to no matches, the longest
ambiguous bindings that caused the pending state are temporarily disabled and
the previous keystrokes are replayed. If there is ambiguity again during the
replay, the next longest bindings are disabled and the keystrokes are replayed
again.
